text: Which English king was known as 'Longshanks' and famously expelled all Jews from England in 1290?
explanation: Edward I was nicknamed 'Longshanks' due to his height and issued the Edict of Expulsion in 1290.
detailedExplanation: Edward I of England (1239-1307) earned the nickname 'Longshanks' because of his unusual height for the medieval period, standing over 6 feet tall. In 1290, he issued the Edict of Expulsion, which ordered all Jews to leave England by November 1st of that year. This made England the first European country to expel its entire Jewish population, and Jews were not officially readmitted until Oliver Cromwell's time in the 1650s. Edward I was also known for his military campaigns in Wales and Scotland.

text: Who was the last Stuart monarch to rule Britain before the House of Hanover took the throne?
explanation: Queen Anne was the last Stuart monarch, ruling from 1702-1714 before George I of Hanover became king.
detailedExplanation: Queen Anne (1665-1714) was the last monarch from the House of Stuart to rule Britain. She reigned from 1702 until her death in 1714, during which time the Act of Union 1707 united England and Scotland into the Kingdom of Great Britain. Anne had no surviving children despite 17 pregnancies, which led to the succession passing to the House of Hanover under the Act of Settlement 1701. George I, Elector of Hanover and Anne's second cousin, became king in 1714, beginning the Hanoverian dynasty.
citationTitle: Wikipedia: Anne, Queen of Great Britain

text: Which medieval English king died at the age of 15 and was posthumously declared a saint by the Catholic Church?
explanation: Edward the Martyr was murdered at age 15-18 in 978 and later canonized as a saint.
detailedExplanation: Edward the Martyr (c. 962-978) became King of England in 975 at around age 13, but his reign was short-lived and contentious. He was murdered at Corfe Castle in 978, likely on the orders of his stepmother Ælfthryh, who wanted her own son Æthelred to become king. Edward was killed by being stabbed while still mounted on his horse. Due to the circumstances of his death and reported miracles at his tomb, he was canonized as a saint by the Catholic Church. His feast day is March 18th, and he is remembered as a martyr who died for political rather than religious reasons.

text: What was the regnal name of the monarch who abdicated in 1936 and later became the Duke of Windsor?
explanation: Edward VIII abdicated in December 1936 to marry Wallis Simpson and became the Duke of Windsor.
detailedExplanation: Edward VIII (1894-1972) reigned for only 326 days in 1936 before abdicating to marry American divorcée Wallis Simpson. Born David, he took the regnal name Edward VIII upon becoming king after his father George V's death in January 1936. His decision to marry Simpson, who had been divorced twice, created a constitutional crisis as the Church of England (of which he was Supreme Governor) did not permit remarriage after divorce. After abdicating in December 1936, he was given the title Duke of Windsor by his brother, who became George VI.

text: Which Tudor monarch's wife was executed for adultery and treason just 19 days after being charged?
explanation: Catherine Howard, fifth wife of Henry VIII, was executed in February 1542 just 19 days after being charged.
detailedExplanation: Catherine Howard (c. 1521-1542), the fifth wife of Henry VIII, was arrested in November 1541 on charges of adultery and treason. She was accused of having relationships with Henry Manox, Francis Dereham, and Thomas Culpeper both before and during her marriage to the king. After being charged on January 21, 1542, she was executed by beheading on February 13, 1542, just 19 days later. She was approximately 19-21 years old at the time of her death. The speed of her trial and execution reflected Henry VIII's fury at what he perceived as her betrayal.

text: What was the name of the last Anglo-Saxon king of England who died at the Battle of Hastings?
explanation: Harold Godwinson (Harold II) was the last Anglo-Saxon king, killed at Hastings in 1066.
detailedExplanation: Harold Godwinson, also known as Harold II (c. 1022-1066), was the last Anglo-Saxon king of England. He ruled for only nine months in 1066 before being killed at the Battle of Hastings on October 14, 1066. Harold had to fight two major battles in quick succession - first defeating Harald Hardrada and his own brother Tostig at Stamford Bridge in September, then marching south to face William of Normandy at Hastings. His death marked the end of Anglo-Saxon rule in England and the beginning of Norman control under William the Conqueror.

text: Which British monarch was the first to live in Buckingham Palace as their primary residence?
explanation: Queen Victoria was the first monarch to use Buckingham Palace as the primary royal residence from 1837.
detailedExplanation: Queen Victoria (1819-1901) was the first British monarch to make Buckingham Palace her primary London residence when she ascended to the throne in 1837. The palace was originally built as Buckingham House for the Duke of Buckingham in 1703, then acquired by George III in 1761. George IV began extensive renovations in the 1820s, but died before completion. William IV never lived there, preferring Clarence House. Victoria moved in shortly after becoming queen and held her first official court there in 1838. The palace has remained the primary residence of British monarchs ever since.

text: Which medieval king was known as 'the Unready' and paid Danegeld to Viking invaders?
explanation: Æthelred II 'the Unready' ruled from 978-1016 and frequently paid Danegeld tribute to Vikings.
detailedExplanation: Æthelred II (c. 966-1016), known as 'Æthelred the Unready,' ruled England from 978 to 1016 with a brief interruption. The epithet 'Unready' comes from 'unræd,' meaning 'poorly advised' or 'no counsel,' a play on his name which meant 'noble counsel.' His reign was marked by renewed Viking raids, and rather than fight, he often chose to pay Danegeld - tribute money to buy off the invaders. Between 991 and 1012, enormous sums were paid to Vikings, including 10,000 pounds of silver in 991 and 48,000 pounds in 1012. This policy ultimately proved ineffective and bankrupted the kingdom.

text: Which royal house ruled England immediately before the Tudors took power in 1485?
explanation: The House of York was the last ruling house before Henry Tudor defeated Richard III at Bosworth Field in 1485.
detailedExplanation: The House of York ruled England from 1461 to 1485, with Edward IV, Edward V, and Richard III as its monarchs. This period was marked by the Wars of the Roses, a series of civil wars between the Houses of York and Lancaster. The Yorkist rule ended when Henry Tudor (later Henry VII) defeated Richard III at the Battle of Bosworth Field in 1485, establishing the Tudor dynasty and ending the Plantagenet era.

text: Which monarch was on the throne during the South Sea Bubble financial crisis of 1720?
explanation: George I was king during the South Sea Bubble crisis, one of Britain's first major stock market crashes in 1720.
detailedExplanation: The South Sea Bubble was a financial crisis that occurred in 1720 during the reign of George I (1714-1727). The South Sea Company's stock price inflated dramatically based on speculation about profits from trade with South America, before crashing spectacularly. The crisis nearly brought down the government and ruined many investors, including members of the royal court. Sir Robert Walpole helped resolve the crisis and subsequently became Britain's first Prime Minister.

text: Which English queen was married to Philip II of Spain but died childless after a five-year reign?
explanation: Mary I married Philip II of Spain in 1554 and reigned for five years (1553-1558) but died without producing an heir.
detailedExplanation: Mary I, known as 'Bloody Mary,' reigned from 1553 to 1558 and married Philip II of Spain in 1554 as part of her effort to restore Catholicism to England. Despite her fervent desire for a Catholic heir and her belief that she had experienced phantom pregnancies, she died childless in 1558. Her marriage to Philip was deeply unpopular with the English people, and her persecution of Protestants earned her the infamous nickname. She was succeeded by her Protestant half-sister Elizabeth I.

text: Which king was forced to agree to the Provisions of Oxford in 1258, limiting royal power?
explanation: Henry III was compelled by rebel barons led by Simon de Montfort to accept the Provisions of Oxford, which restricted his authority.
detailedExplanation: The Provisions of Oxford were imposed on Henry III in 1258 by a group of rebel barons led by Simon de Montfort. These provisions established a council of 15 barons to oversee royal decisions and effectively limited the king's power, similar to how Magna Carta had restricted King John's authority earlier. The provisions were part of the broader baronial reform movement and led to the Second Barons' War. Though Henry III later repudiated the provisions, they represented a significant early step in the constitutional limitation of royal power in England.

text: Who was the last British monarch to personally lead troops into battle?
explanation: George II was the last British king to personally command troops in battle, at Dettingen in 1743 during the War of Austrian Succession.
detailedExplanation: George II holds the distinction of being the last British monarch to personally lead troops into battle. This occurred at the Battle of Dettingen on June 27, 1743, during the War of Austrian Succession. The 60-year-old king fought alongside his men in what was ultimately a victory for the Anglo-Austrian forces against the French. His horse bolted during the battle, forcing him to fight on foot, but he showed considerable personal courage. No British monarch since has personally commanded troops in active combat.

text: Which medieval English king was deposed twice during his reign and died in the Tower of London?
explanation: Henry VI was deposed during the Wars of the Roses in 1461 and again in 1471, dying in the Tower of London shortly after his final capture.
detailedExplanation: Henry VI had one of the most turbulent reigns in English history, being deposed twice during the Wars of the Roses. First deposed in 1461 by Edward IV of York, he was restored to the throne briefly in 1470-1471 during the 'Readeption.' He was captured again after the Battle of Tewkesbury in 1471 and died in the Tower of London on May 21, 1471, officially of melancholy but likely murdered. His mental illness and weak rule contributed significantly to the outbreak of the Wars of the Roses between the houses of Lancaster and York.

text: Which Stewart monarch of Scotland also briefly became King of England for just over a year before being executed?
explanation: Charles I was king of both Scotland and England, ruling England from 1625-1649 before being executed during the English Civil War.
detailedExplanation: Charles I ruled as King of England, Scotland, and Ireland from 1625 until his execution in 1649. As a member of the House of Stewart (Stuart), he inherited both the Scottish and English crowns from his father James I/VI. His conflicts with Parliament over royal prerogatives and religious policies led to the English Civil War. After his defeat, he was tried for treason and executed on January 30, 1649, making him the only British monarch to be formally executed. His death led to the establishment of the Commonwealth under Oliver Cromwell.

text: Which English monarch was known as 'The Unready' and ruled during two separate periods due to Viking invasions?
explanation: Æthelred II was called 'The Unready' (meaning 'ill-advised') and ruled 978-1013 and 1014-1016.
detailedExplanation: Æthelred II, known as 'Æthelred the Unready,' ruled England from 978 to 1013 and again from 1014 to 1016. The epithet 'Unready' is a mistranslation of the Old English 'unræd,' meaning 'ill-advised' or 'poorly counseled,' not 'unprepared.' His reign was marked by constant Viking raids and the eventual conquest by Sweyn Forkbeard of Denmark in 1013, forcing Æthelred into exile. He returned after Sweyn's death in 1014 but died in 1016, leaving a legacy of failed attempts to buy off Viking invaders with increasingly large payments of Danegeld.

text: Who was the only British monarch to be born in Hanover and never learn to speak English fluently?
explanation: George I was born in Hanover in 1660 and primarily spoke German and French throughout his life.
detailedExplanation: George I became King of Great Britain and Ireland in 1714 following the death of Queen Anne, establishing the House of Hanover's rule. Born Georg Ludwig in Hanover in 1660, he was already 54 when he ascended to the British throne. Having spent his entire life in the German states, he never mastered English and conducted most of his business in French, which was the diplomatic language of the era. This language barrier contributed to his reliance on his ministers, particularly Sir Robert Walpole, who is often considered Britain's first Prime Minister. George I's unfamiliarity with English customs and language made him an outsider to British society, though his reign marked the beginning of the constitutional monarchy's modern form.
citationTitle: Wikipedia: George I of Great Britain

text: Which medieval English queen was accused of adultery with multiple men, including her own brother, leading to her execution in 1536?
explanation: Anne Boleyn was executed on charges of adultery, including allegedly with her brother George Boleyn, though historians debate the validity of these charges.
detailedExplanation: Anne Boleyn, Henry VIII's second wife and mother of Elizabeth I, was arrested in May 1536 on charges of adultery with five men, including her brother George Boleyn, Lord Rochford. The accusations also included courtiers Henry Norris, William Brereton, Francis Weston, and court musician Mark Smeaton. Modern historians largely agree that these charges were fabricated by Henry VIII and his chief minister Thomas Cromwell to enable the king's marriage to Jane Seymore. The evidence was circumstantial at best, and the speed of the trials suggests a predetermined outcome. Anne was executed by sword at the Tower of London on May 19, 1536, becoming the first English queen to be publicly executed.

text: Which Stuart monarch was known as the 'Winter Queen' and was briefly Queen of Bohemia for just one winter?
explanation: Elizabeth Stuart, daughter of James I, became Queen of Bohemia in 1619 but lost the throne after the Battle of White Mountain in 1620.
detailedExplanation: Elizabeth Stuart (1596-1662), daughter of James I of England and VI of Scotland, married Frederick V, Elector Palatine, in 1613. When Frederick accepted the crown of Bohemia in 1619 following the Defenestration of Prague, Elizabeth became Queen of Bohemia. However, their reign lasted only from November 1619 to November 1620, when Frederick was defeated at the Battle of White Mountain by Catholic forces. This brief reign earned her the nickname 'Winter Queen.' The couple spent the rest of their lives in exile in the Dutch Republic. Elizabeth's daughter Sophia became Electress of Hanover, and through the Act of Settlement 1701, Elizabeth became the grandmother of George I, making her an important link between the Stuart and Hanoverian dynasties.
citationTitle: Wikipedia: Elizabeth Stuart, Queen of Bohemia

text: Which English king was known as 'Lackland' and lost most of the Angevin Empire's continental territories to Philip II of France?
explanation: King John was nicknamed 'Lackland' because he lost most English territories in France.
detailedExplanation: King John (r. 1199-1216) earned the nickname 'Lackland' (originally given because as the youngest son he was expected to inherit no land) due to his military failures against Philip II Augustus of France. During his reign, John lost Normandy, Anjou, Maine, and most other Angevin possessions in France, effectively ending the Angevin Empire that had been built by his predecessors. His losses were so significant that by 1204, England retained only Gascony and parts of Poitou on the continent, marking a dramatic reduction in English territorial power in France.
